items.title: The Value of Art
items.content_html:
Speaking as both a (largely wildly â€˜unsuccessfulâ€™) musician and a corporate strategic consultant type, the conclusion Iâ€™ve come to of late is that the music industry can only ethically exist if it de-emphasises product/content/output as a determinant of value.

When you refer to the de-emphasis of artists via playlisting, I think of it as the logical culmination of a trajectory that began as far back as with early blues releases (if not further) and was only ever going to lead to AI slop - detaching the mechanics of value from the origin of the output. It wasnâ€™t the artist that was valuable, it was the specific art. And, now, we move to â€˜itâ€™s not the specific art thatâ€™s valuable, but the vibeâ€™.

But, in refuting that, I think we often fall into the trap of affirming the product-focus approach - â€˜the artist is valuable because they create artâ€™ - and continue to keep the creatorâ€™s value detached from their actual function. Because, the value of art has never been in how good or bad it is but in the people it connects. This is the function that art performs, in terms of social, health, economic, and community benefits. It is a mechanism through which we commune, reflect, connect, and decide upon our worldâ€™s values. And, thatâ€™s where the economic focus should be - supporting that mechanism.

Itâ€™s why I find the AI art and tech world mostly amusing. Theyâ€™re refining and investing in recreating the product. But, the product is the least valuable part of the whole equation. You want to churn out a polished song in a couple of minutes? You donâ€™t need AI - I (and lots of other people) can do that. The difficult part is getting people to come together. And, the more you detach a human investment from that process, the harder it will be to accomplish that. Especially if you donâ€™t realise THATâ€™s the important part.

So, I think the solution is - forget content, embrace community, disregard all who prioritise the former at the expense of the latter.

  • Mjoneillnoisier, a comment on a Verge article

I’ve been chewing on this comment ever since I stumbled upon it. I feel like it describes a perspective that I haven’t heard as much in the AI vs art debate. A lot of harm is being done to both artists and audiences when people increasingly give away their agency to passive streams of plesant sounds they barely pay attention to. What’s insulting is that ad companies like Spotify infect this harm into something that used to stand for the opposite: mix tapes.

The mix tape, the mix CD, and human curated playlists were originally mediums of personal musical taste created for people to connect, commune, and reflect over. I’m old enough to have mixes from old friends that I still listen to. They are experiential reminders that take me to people, places, and life events. It sucks when corporations conspire to eradicate a vibrant part of our shared culture.

items.content_html:
We contain multitudes, all of us, even the worst of us.

From those multitudes, we make things.

Sometimes the things we make come from the light in us. Sometimes they come from the shadows. Usually, making something requires a bit of both.

  • Annie Mueller, When you love something made by a terrible person
